title: Worked Solution
text:
No, events A and B are not independent.

To show this, we can use the formula for the probability of the intersection of two events:

P(A AND B) $$=$$ P(A) * P(B | A)

where P(B | A) is the conditional probability of event B given that event A has occurred.

If events A and B were independent, then we would have:

P(B | A) $$=$$ P(B)

However, in this case, we have:

P(B | A) $$=$$ P(A AND B) / P(A) $$=$$ $$0.02$$ / $$0.1$$ $$=$$ $$0.2$$

which is not equal to P(B) $$=$$ $$0.2$$.

Therefore, events A and B are dependent. The fact that someone is playing football makes it more likely that they are also playing American football, and vice versa.
